title-group.article-title: The Economic Cost of Growing Up Poor: Estimating the GDP Loss Associated with Child Poverty

abstract.p: One of the motivations for the UK government's target to reduce (and eventually eliminate) child poverty is the perception of a significant long-term economic cost of growing up in poverty. This perception arises from the observation that individuals who experience poverty in their childhood earn less as adults, are less likely to be in employment, are more likely to engage in criminal or anti-social activities and are more likely to experience poor health and lower life satisfaction. This paper quantifies these effects, and expresses them in terms of GDP losses to the nation. We begin by focusing on lost earnings that arise from poorer skills and reduced employment opportunities, and then move on to the wider costs associated with the higher crime rates, poorer health and reduced well-being that are linked with growing up poor. We find a sizeable economic cost, with the cost of growing up in poverty amounting to at least 1 per cent of GDP.

p.mixed-citation: Submitted September 2009. This paper emanated from research funded by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation as part of its ■Estimating the Costs of Child Poverty' project. The authors would like to thank Donald Hirsch for helpful comments on the original working paper and an Editor and referees for many useful suggestions. They are also grateful to Mike Brewer of the Institute for Fiscal Studies for providing data on child poverty rates.

Holzer et al. obtain their figures by manipulating estimates of the impact of poverty from existing studies, insisting throughout that they take a 'conservative' approach. We believe our methodology is more transparent; using original analysis enables us to better reveal the impact of different assumptions on the aggregate figures.
The 'less than £100 a week' cut-off is chosen for simplicity as it corresponds to the bottom two categories of the income variable contained in the survey.
This is in large part because there are few categories to choose from in the age 10 income question, so it is difficult to get a good definition of poverty.

There may be some concern that the poverty rate for 16-year-olds will differ from the rate for all children. Investigation of the Family Expenditure Survey indicates that this problem is not too severe as the poverty rate for 14- to 16-year-olds is 18.1 per cent in 1986, only a little below the overall rate.

Blanden and Gregg (2004) review and explore even more stringent tests to identify the causal impact of parental income on children's educational attainment. One way of approaching this is to try to look at within-family or within-individual changes in income. For example, we can look at how children's outcomes evolve between ages 10 and 16 as the level of family income changes. If children's performance deteriorates when their relative income position declines, then we can think of this as a causal effect. When this approach is applied, Blanden and Gregg find that the impacts of family income are still significant but are about one-third of the size of those where family characteristics and test scores are controlled for. However, this approach is likely to be downward biased for two reasons: first, the abolition of child poverty would lead to higher family incomes throughout childhood; and second, these estimates rely on income changes which tend to include a great deal of measurement error.

We have also explored these models using alternative measures of deprivation. Using the same sample, having free school meals at age 16 has a coefficient of -0.187 in the model including test scores, and parent reporting financial difficulties has a coefficient of -0.095. Fewer children report having free school meals than report income of less than £100 a week.
We are also unable to take account of how the impacts of poverty vary according to the length of time poverty is experienced for. This is unavoidable given the nature of our data sources.

The proportion of high-skilled workers is roughly equal to the proportion of workers with degrees in the population, while the LS group is the proportion of workers growing up in poverty (assuming current rates).
The elasticity of substitution is estimated for those leaving school at 18 or below compared with those leaving school at 19 or above.

A third scenario is also possible where not all the LS workers are transformed; this would again limit the increase in GDP that would result from ending child poverty - see Blanden, Hansen and Machin (2008).

See, among others, Layard, Mayraz and Nickell (2008), who relate life satisfaction to income and find that a 1-log-point increase in income increases happiness by 0.52 points on a 0-10 scale. This coefficient is the mean of those reported in table 3 of Layard et al., which includes estimates from a variety of studies and approaches. The estimates range from 0.25 to 0.7.
Results for regressions based on life satisfaction at age 29/30 are strikingly similar, and imply a slight increase of the effect of child poverty on well-being as individuals age.
